Definition: Given a sentence, your responsibility is to classify it into two different classes, which are insult and non-insult. Classify as an insult if the sentence expresses any language that is rude or abusive.

Positive Examples.input: Comment: No wonder Hillary got beat by a circus clown.
Positive Examples.explanation: This comment is insult because it is scornful and disrespectful.

Positive Examples.input: Comment: I guess when you're clueless you stick your head into every hole.
Positive Examples.explanation: This comment is non-insult because it does not disrespect any group.

Negative Examples.input:
Comment: Hillary Clinton was not my girlfriend.

I did not have sexual relations with that woman.
Negative Examples.explanation: This comment might be obscene but not insult.

Negative Examples.input: Comment: She is weak and useless, time to run her off
Negative Examples.explanation: This comment is insult because it is disrespectful.

Comment: As we approach this session, will Mr. Herz be more careful to differentiate between the budget process and the appropriation process.   Senator MacKinnon seems to understand that while the Governor proposes the budget, Senator MacKinnon and her peers must appropriate the necessary funds to support that budget.  I am not accepting even the suggestion that  absent an idiot proof budget plan the legislature cannot do its job (Well, on second thought......).   Also, both sides need to understand that the relationship between the Producers and the State will not be the same in these times of fiscal constraint.  The Producers can maintain their leases and payment to the State by minimum compliance with the law; therefore, if the law only requires a minimum payment on these credits then they should expect the same level of compliance by the State. That is just good business practice.

Comment: Small quibble.

Stupid laws need to be -repealed-. A large part of the problem with our government is the habit of ignoring the system as designed because it is "too hard" (i.e. requires politicians to put their careers on the line by taking stands one way or another) and instead claiming Constitutional requirements "don't work." They then, with the cheering support of idiots who don't understand Civics, punt to either the Courts to decide, or just ignore laws they don't like, and/or make up fixes via administrative regulation workarounds and executive orders.

If we held all levels of government accountable to their actual, limited, Constitutional powers and duties, and as citizens didn't insist on "easy," immediate fixes to problems not actually amenable by government action in the first place, we wouldn't be in this mess.

Comment: Two of the top educational systems in the world are in Singapore and Finland. They have for many years destroyed the US in terms of student outcomes. 

Singapore has a highly structured top-down system with  tightly scripted control of curriculum and testing for all students from the central government. Finland has a similar approach - there is no such thing as a private school - and many credit its success to 1) placing a high national value on the teaching profession and paying teachers accordingly and 2) paid high-quality universal preschool and daycare for all kids ages 3-7.

Neither country touts "school choice". They have committed to, and invest appropriately, in a consistent and top notch universal education for ALL of their country's students.  

But don't let facts get in the way of your effort to tear apart the US educational system. Carry-on with your ignorance...

Comment: Rik... man, you really have a stick up your arse don't you? First off, the dams were ancient, and unless you wanted to spend millions more to repair them only to repair them again in another few years, it was best to take them down. Add in the increased cost of maintenance, and it would be prohibitive. 

Second, the habitat gained by removal has, amazing as it might seem to you, been used by salmon, and used quite extensively. In fact, not only have they traveled deep into the park, but they have spawned, quite successfully in fact, throughout the river and tributaries opened up by dam removal. Salmon, as it turns out, are a very real source of income for thousands of fisherman across the state, and up in Alaska...  

Third, the fix you suggest for US 101 is absurd, and a hell of a lot more expensive and potentially dangerous than building a new bridge. Maybe you don't realize how much rock would have to be moved, but it would be prohibitive and destabilizing to the hillside.

Comment: No doubt WWI was a foolish war that ended so badly WWII was bound to follow; the treaty was poorly done.

But there is a certain truth to the assertion that it made Canada a nation.  I agree with Ms Wente in that it is difficult to find nation building stories, since unlike most countries, Canada slowly evolved to nationhood.  We have no revolution to glorify, and we have never had conflict on our own soil except as a colony.  Illustrious tales are few, we slogged our way into nationhood, and the first seeds were sown not by us but by Britain in 1867.  WWI proved we could stand on our own.

As an aside, I am saddened by Wilson-Raybould 's remark that it is “hard to celebrate 150 years of colonialism.”  Aboriginals got a raw deal, true enough, but even though our history has its share of lamentable events, we have also done much to be proud of.  I can't think of a country I would rather live in.  If Mr Wilson-Raybould is ashamed of his country he has no business in cabinet.

Comment: High income earners pay the lions share of all taxes so it is inevitable that anything that reduces taxes will disproportionately benefit higher income earners.

Put another way, if someone is only paying $20/year in total income taxes, the most you can possibly cut their taxes by is $20, or a 100% decrease. "... companies are woefully behind on their cleanup obligations. Of the 177,719 acres disturbed by mining in Wyoming, only 9 percent, or 16,141 acres, can be considered officially reclaimed, they note."

"At the close of the last fiscal year, roughly 69,000 acres, or 39 percent of all disturbed acres in Wyoming, were in phase one [backfilling], according to the U.S. Office of Surface Mining Reclamation and Enforcement. The officially reclaimed acres, those having achieved phase three [10 year monitoring], account for that 9 percent referenced by environmentalists.

Comment: Mahalo Warren, well said.  Local culture is an amalgam of the many distinct cultures of Hawaii's earlier era.  By "earlier era" I when at time in our history when English was not the common language.  Therefore, your actions and how you interacted with others was paramount.  For many residents who are born and raised in Hawaii, local culture refers to this shared experience, history and values.  Warren's reference at times to "enryo" and other commonly known Japnese terms for shared local culture makes sense given his personal perspective.  If he used Hawaiian terms for these same values, he might have been accused of misappropriation.  In the end, his primary point is the importance of being civil.  In Hawaii, Aloha, Pono, and Lokahi are Hawaiian terms that have importance and relevance to Warren's points.  In these times where people are loose with their words and actions, and instant gratification over rides self-discipline, civility is all the more necessary.

Comment: The fact that a certain segment of the U.S. population is susceptible to, perhaps even inclined toward, a fascist/authoritarian leader is not new. Whether Trumpery represents a more significant or lasting expression of fascism than previous manifestations of the fascist impulse remains to be seen, but it would be, I think, a serious mistake to think that he's going away on Nov. 9.

In the 1930s, as the world was deep in Depression and fascists were on the rise in Germany, Spain, Italy and elsewhere, Sinclair Lewis published a cautionary tale, "It Can't Happen Here."  The blurb on the jacket of the 2014 imprint calls it "a shockingly prescient novel ...", and so it is.

Comment: The headline (Mixed marriages lead to fewer Catholic children) is catchy, but misleading.

Let's consider what happens using two groups of men and women.  Half of each group is Catholic, the rest are non-Catholic.  When two of the Catholics marry, 62% of the time the children will be Catholic.  But when two of the non-Catholics marry, the likely that their children will be Catholic would be nearly 0%.  So, on average, just 31% of all the children would be Catholic.

When two Catholics marry a non-Catholic rather each other, there are twice as many marriages with a Catholic spouse.  According to the Pew survey, when Catholics marry Protestants, 29% of all the children would be Catholic.  If we change Protestant to no particular faith, 32% of all the children from the two marriages would be Catholic.  So in the end, the total number of Catholic children would be roughly the same (and almost certainly within the margin of error) with or without mixed marriages.

Comment: It's not that I don't agree with the premise of the article (I do) but I take exception with the categorization of  the Establishing Mandatory Minimums for Illegal Reentry Act of 2015 as: "respond(ing) with draconian punishments to address a drastically-overstated problem."
In reality, there is a large number of the 11,000,000+ illegals that have been deported & have illegally returned to our country. That is not to say that they all have committed additional crimes, but as it stands now, flaunting our immigration laws is a civil matter & not criminal. What Kate's Law does is add some heft to our immigration policy to help deter continual flaunting of said policy. It would have been better, in my opinion, had our elected officials actually criminalized illegal entry in the first place. If you are here illegally, you should be arrested, jailed & then deported. That is what we do if someone breaks into a house, so why should breaking into the country be any less severely punished?

Comment: I believe there is only one practical solution here, which is to spend a lot of money to beef up the refugee determination process. Additionally, to comply with Charter requirements, a new federal court specifically dedicated to refugee appeals should be established. And strict timelines should be applied. All initial claims should be addressed within six months of entry and all appeals should be determined within two years of entry. Were the process actually efficient, a lot of claimants would be discouraged from entering the country in the first place. Spending the money to bolster the efficiency and legitimacy of the system will save us billions of dollars in the long run.

Comment: We could do away with the Electoral College and still be a republic. How much understanding do you have about how this system came to be?

The founding fathers did not envision political parties, and the electors were supposed to act as “filter” between the people and the White House, exercise independent judgment, not vote the party line. 

Hamilton wrote in The Federalist Papers No. 68:

"The process of election affords a moral certainty, that the office of President will never fall to the lot of any man who is not in an eminent degree endowed with the requisite qualifications. Talents for low intrigue, and the little arts of popularity, may alone suffice to elevate a man to the first honors..." 

Talents for low intrigue and the little arts of popularity, describe Trump to a tee. A system designed to prevent the people from choosing an unqualified demagogue has resulted in the election of an unqualified demagogue not chosen by the people.

Comment: There are already a few good on-line butchers in Ontario:   Eg:  Slipacoff's in Ottawa.    They offer eg:  dry aged steaks, some 70 days.    I've ordered from them and have been very satisfied.

If you're in Toronto there are a number of very good butchers too.     The problem I find with most grocery butchers is the age of the meat.    A lot of the beef is almost like veal, young, too fresh and tasteless.     A good butcher who offers dry aged beef is well worth the premium whether its local or online.      

As for BBQ'ing, I'm a year rounder - but lately have preferred doing steaks on a cast iron pan, finished with butter.     I get a far better sear, even if serving blue rare, because I can get the pan far hotter than a gas bbq in winter.     Then I let it rest, raised off the plate.      Now, I'm hungry....

Comment: Sad, even though the band's best days were close to 40 years ago.

Many years ago I dated a girl from south Jersey.  Her best friend told me about one night she saw the band headlining at the Philadelphia Spectrum (late 70's), where they finished the show around 11, then played three more encores that took the thing out to somewhere around 2 in the morning before the house lights went up and people started to leave.  She got up like everyone else and started the zombie shuffle toward the doors when Peter Wolf came bounding back on stage (after somewhere between three and four hours of destroying his voice) and yelled "where the @#$% are you goin'?  We came to party" and did another hour long encore with the house lights up.

Even as played by a bunch of senior citizens their music had terrific energy.  RIP.

Comment: "Even if they are not qualified or even interested in coding. They have to be forced to do it. It's 2017!"

My wife took FORTRAN coding along with other Academic Math students in her Class of 1972 High School cohort. She started out with an Honours Microbiology Degree, but like many of the people in that class ended up pushing gigabytes around for a living. 

Female enrolment in CSc was about 1 in 3 up until the 1980, when it dropped to 1 in 10 when the first K-12 victims of an experimental math curriculum showed up at post secondary institutions. Enrolment in math intensive areas, chem, engr, math, phys, stats dropped for both male and female and math profs found that students were arriving in need of remedial math teaching, compare to the "new math" that was so successful in the 1960s.

The move away from standardised math achievement tests probably hid the failure of the new program. Avoiding reality checks hides poor teaching methods, not just dud teachers.

Comment: #1
Yeah team, someone else knows about the genius of Dix!!! Long live the Dom. 

Liturgical scholarship prior to Dix was inherently ecumenical--a key method was "comparative liturgy." In order to make sense of the evolution of individual traditions, one had to study the meager early evidence for all rites. Dix brought that all together masterfully.

Since then, Roman liturgists appear to know much less about other rites, especially the Byzantine. Since all liturgical renovations moved from East to West--from Jerusalem to Byzantium to Rome--for Roman scholars to not know about Byzantine developments is to not understand oneself.

Here is a perfect example.

The present Easter Vigil is a very long service, consisting of three major parts: (1) a Liturgy of the Word with uniquely seven readings, (2) an extended Baptism and Confirmation Service, and (3) the Eucharist.

This liturgy was adopted from the Byzantine Easter Vigil in the 8th century, with one fundamental misunderstanding.

Many rural AK folk are "unbanked" similarly to rural folks in many African countries (they do not have easy access to physical banks, and often lack the knowledge or capital to establish banking or credit services). Comment: I don't believe high pressure steam systems are your average plumbing system Michael. What if the system was designed and built to withstand 300#psi operation, and the 100# safety relief valve had to be temporary taken out of service so the system (as per contract) could be tested and proven to function at 75% or better of the design capacity. And thanks to the hammering, they determined faulty components of the system, corrected those problems and reinstalled the relief valve prior to regular operation of the system. Would you still be pushing for $882,000.00 in fines?

Comment: If one looks at the US Fed’s preferred measure of core inflation, PCEPILFE, the annual inflation rate was 1.7% in January 2017, the same as in December 2016, and still quite a bit lower than the 2% target rate. On the other hand, the annualized three-month rate of change in prices was at 1.9% in January, almost double the 1.1% rate in December. So the US Fed really can justify a rate hike, especially as house prices, excluded from the PCEPI, have been rising strongly, at a 6% rate or close to it.

Comment: Out here, it's my wife and I and a cat-sized cat. The thousand feet is the main floor, where the housework is concentrated. There is also a bathroom, store-room, a third bedroom, and laundry in the basement, but I just tend to them when we've got people staying. The place is around 1600 feet in all. My wife bought large because at the time it looked like she'd need to make a home for her sister and her child as well, but then things worked out differently, and now the sister, child, and child's father live in an apartment upstairs. We did have my mother-in-law here for four years, but she's moved on to a senior community 1//2 hour away. 

We started out 36 years ago in a two room dirt floored shack, with a tin stove and no plumbing, electricity off an extension cord. We were very happy, so it was a palace. Our current digs are just as good.

Comment: My view is a little more nuanced, having had close friends who were "PKs" (Preacher's kids). I don't think anyone, married or celibate, should be ordained before 40 without special circumstances. Men with families should be ordained only after the children are grown. The pressure on clergy families is immense, and the children deserve a normal childhood. The word "presbyter" from which "priest" comes has Greek roots associated with "old man", suggesting that the earliest "priests" were elders, not 20-somethings. But for this change to work, the role of priest as the primary leader of the church must change, too, so he can work outside the parish and let laity control more community services and functions. This would equalize power and make the parish a true body where many gifts are recognized and used. Married clergy without an older ordination age and  change in lay roles would solve only part of the problem.  Celibate or married makes no difference.

Comment: Part of Reconciliation means that both parties - Indigenous and non-Indigenous, need to begin thinking and acting outside the box on so many issues which affect our nation-to-nation relationship: from housing, to education, to resource sharing, the list goes on and on! Very near the top of that neglected list is the pandemic of youth suicides in remote First Nations communities. Immediate and effective stop-gap measures are required. For the long-haul, however,  simply throwing money at a porous wall hoping that it will stick is rarely the solution. Vital to resolving this tragic problem and so many others that plague our Indigenous brothers and sisters is to begin considering the very viability of remote northern First Nation reserves. The pervasive lack of opportunity, crumbling infrastructure and the persistence of legacy issues oozing from soul-killing residential schools are and will continue to be generational. For Indigenos youth that toxic combination gives death to dreams.

The same is in the works here for the pipeline and organizers who know very well how to do it again went into action immediately after Trudeau's announcement. Comment: Say today you become homeless. You have no friends /relatives with space to take you. For some it would violate their lease to have you live with them, without notifying the land lord first.  You decide to move into a shelter. You discover some shelters have a 1-3 month waiting list to get in, Yes, you get turned away.  

You go to another shelter and say, "I want to move in" Great ! We will put you on the waiting list. Here is a stack of forms that needs filled out BEFORE you can get on the waiting list.

For each member of the family : we need copies of your birth certificates, Copies of your state ID's, of your social security cards, immunization records for kids, TB test clearances. Income statements and possibly bank statements. Copies of your I94's if you are COFA participants (it is $300 each to replace them if you lost them, and can take 6 months to get them.) 

Once you have all of that, then you can start to fill out your paperwork to move in. Do you have that with you today?

Comment: Irving was never a heavy oil refinery.

Comment: "Canada is the number two exporter of Natural Gas in the world, Number one, Qatar."

Incorrect.
Russia is #1 (by quite a bit), then Qatar. Even Norway is still ahead of Canada. Meanwhile, US gas exports are surging on multiple fronts: as LNG via Louisiana and by pipeline to Mexico and Ontario.

Exports of Cdn gas to USA peaked in 2002 for two reasons: our production of conventional gas was peaking (and is now in terminal decline) and USA was beginning to exploit its massive reserves of shale gas. US gas is dirt cheap which is why southern Ontario is increasingly burning Marcellus gas as opposed to Cdn gas from out west.

Comment: The inherent problem with FN costs is that most of the treaties were made when FN members resided in an almost "self sufficient" community. Over the decades they have become more accustomed to goods and services that are not readily available in their local community, which leads to very high costs. There is no doubt that if treaties were negotiated today, they would be vastly different. In addition to financial costs, there are a growing number of social costs related to remote reserves. Drug and alcohol problems, teen suicides, poor living conditions and possibly MMIW are all related to "life on a reserve". The concept of a "remote reserve" does not fit in today's society.

Rape is NOT up 70%.  The definition of rape, in Sweden, was massively broadened in 2005, and again in 2013.  This accounts for the vast majority of the "increase" as can be seen in the commensurate "decrease" in those crimes formerly tagged, before the definition change.
You will also see a claim that some 70% of rapes, in Sweden, are perpetrated by refugees/migrants/muslins/etc.  This data is ABSOLUTELY FALSE. Comment: "Shame the country never listened to Eisenhower, the last republican president who actually balanced the budget."

Under Ike in the 1950's, the top marginal tax on personal income was above 90%, and the USA had full employment, expanding middle class, good health and pensions, strong unions, affordable education, small prison population, small federal budget, and the world's most innovative and prosperous economy. High top income tax forced productivity to be reinvested into business. 

Since the Reagan cut taxes to below 35%, US productivity gains have largely been extracted as obscene personal profit by wealthy business owners and overpaid executives. The result is the widening income gap, luxury economy, risky unethical business conduct, money politics, less workforce investment and middle class opportunity, a demoralized population, crumbling infrastructure, and expanded prisons and welfare programs to prevent civil unrest.

I liked Ike, when America was truly great.

Comment: It would be nice to have more civil and reasoned discourse.   Generally, conservative leaning folks like to control others as much as us far out progressives.   But...there are issues on both sides.  And almost nobody is stupid just because I...or you...disagree with them.

For starters, I smoked quite a bit when my now adult offspring were children.  I chose never to smoke in the car with them or to smoke in the kitchen when I was preparing food.   And I never asked my children to fetch my cigarettes or lighter from across the room or at the store.  

I would like others to not smoke in cars with kids also but I am not in favor of a law.  Helmet laws and putting fluoride in the water to protect my teeth and those of little ones make sense to me.

I agree we have to be careful not to pass too many control freak laws (no RV's parked in suburban driveways??), and laws about smoking in the car will be difficult to enforce.  Get people off their cell phones while driving first....

Comment: Not that I'm feeling particularly ornery this morning, but...

"Hollywood conventionally manipulates stories and their endings for emotional effect ..."  Yup.  Movie-makers used the trick in cheap-jack "studios" in New York and New Jersey, long before there was a Hollywood.  Learned  from writers who published novels.   So? It works. Always has.  Always will.  

“based on a true story” works, too.  Many people feel "made up" fictional stories aren't as good as non-fiction. Hell, my father got bent watching Titanic in 1997 (he remembered 1958's "true" British, A Night to Remember; this one would be better because it was in colour).  Oh, no!  They stuck a love story right in the middle of it!  Dad was weird like that: the 1997 blockbuster made gobs of money. "Night" hardly broke even. 

Happy endings aren't the only thing contrived.  With odd exceptions, until the late 50s, the whole movie experience was based on fantasy.  One movie cured me of all that: Easy Rider. Now I'm bent, too...

Comment: Being able to legally build a loft for sleeping (one can already build a loft that one isn't able to sleep in) is hardly the making of a slum. In fact, with our beautiful evening and night skies, many friends of mine have modified their homes so that they sleep in lofts under skylights. None of them would have done so if they hadn't found a way around the stairway problem. 

Heck, my niece lives in a half-million dollar home that has a ladder to a loft that pre-dates current code. She would like to upgrade the ladder but isn't allowed to unless she converts it to a stairway, which just won't fit. There's nothing remotely slum-like about her home with a loft.

We probably agree that our building codes need to be upgraded and enforced. However, allowing people to use ladders to access sleeping quarters is where we may have to agree to disagree.

Comment: I live in a rural area.. I have done everything I can do to lower my electric power consumption. My bill rises as my consumption lowers. They applied for a rate increase, and got it. We were penalized for doing exactly what they asked us to do.  It's absolutely no exaggeration to say that many people - especially those on fixed incomes - must choose between heat and food. That little rebate gift that Wynne decided to dole out to the rural dwellers will be eaten up by the carbon tax. As I write this, it's -20C outside, and dropping. There's 2 ft of snow in my backyard.  If Wynne wants to come and stay with us, she'd better bring some heavy sweaters. She,ll need them.

Comment: GS, the example you raise further indicates the negative bias that the tribunal displayed at every turn. Camp's interlocuters said he could benefit from instruction on sexism and sexual assault law. Camp described his views as "old-fashioned." From those facts, which are not in themselves exclusionary, the tribunal concluded that Camp was an incorrigible misogynist and beyond re-education.

I can understand the sentiment that Justice Camp should suffer the worst punishment available in these circumstances. But as you point out, the role of judges is to be IMPARTIAL. The judges on the tribunal failed in their duty to consider the matter fairly and without bias. Time and time again the tribunal chose the most negative interpretation of Camp's words.. No benefit of the doubt was given. Worse yet, as in the example I offered above, even when Camp's words were themselves innocuous, the tribunal drew the the most damning conclusion it could.

Comment: The rifle should have been unloaded after the game was taken.  Slings break and accidental discharges happen with loaded firearms.  No firearm should be carried loaded unless it is ready to be discharged at its intended target.  There was no reason for this firearm to be loaded.

Someone here says that no firearm should have a chambered cartridge until the target is in sight.  This is false.  I have hunted large game for almost 60 years, and I have hunted safely.  When the target comes into sight, the hunter doesn't have time to chamber a cartridge, the time frame is a matter of seconds.  The rifle is carried loaded and cocked, with the safety engaged.  The hunter takes his stance, disengages the safety, takes final aim, and fires.  This should be done in three seconds, and if the hunter is competent, the first shot will result in the animal's death within another ten seconds.

After the kill, the firearm should have been unloaded.  Too bad.

Comment: I certainly agree that when a law is immoral, it is not a valid law.  Glad to see you agree with Natural Law, which I believe is the only basis for our agreed-upon position on that point.

That said, Natural Law and positive law agree that a nation has the right to control and protect its borders.  The people of the United States have said we have a right to enforce our borders by punishing those who harbor those who have come here illegally.  Since you probably agree --- or maybe you don't --- that there's a presumption that our laws are valid, how do you overcome the presumed validity of our harboring statute?  In other words, what argument do you have that the harboring statute is immoral?  

In what sense is our harboring statute like Jim Crow laws?  Do you honestly believe they are sufficiently similar to allow a useful analogy?

The artist can then  "cap" the ticket re-sale at face value and nobody will be able to resell that ticket above what they paid.  If the "bots" can't sell a ticket for a profit. But done in a different way so the person doesn't have to physically be stopped for an ID check.

Comment: Well some form of proportional representation does give more people a voice and may increase our low voter turnout. But I suppose many think a low voter turnout is also good for stability ....... who wants the fringe and the unwanted voting and disturbing the status quo. Many don't vote because their vote has no influence, no voice (a liberal in Lethbridge, a conservative in parts of Quebec).. 

How about a system that combines both? One vote for the first past the post representative and using that vote for proportional representation. A third of seats for PR based simply on the vote. No ranking, no second votes, no complications. A liberal in Calgary can vote liberal knowing the seat will be lost but their vote will count. You get the stability of the current system, but every vote has an influence.

Comment: I appreciate your first paragraph very much.   However, I cannot understand why you believe there has been a decline in global temperatures.   Through the month of August, 2016 has been the hottest year on record, following the previous hottest year in 2015, which followed the previous hottest year on record in 2014.     It was 2015 when global temperatures were recorded at 1C above pre-industrial temperatures.   That took over 165 years of industrial civilization to bring about.   It took less than 5 months to see a global average temperature of 1.5C.

While the ice cap has gone up and down, and had years where the melt didn't vary that much, it has also steadily declined overall, to the point that fully a third-plus of its mass is gone.   This graph illustrates the pattern well.
http://haveland.com/share/arctic-death-spiral.png

The smaller it gets, the faster it melts.

Comment: It's not a terrible point. As another example, why don't we see any outrage over the India pale ale?  After all, it was literally invented so that imperialists could get drunk on British-made beer (in turn, presumably, making things rather more unpleasant for the Indians).

That doesn't mean we should turn a blind eye to the crimes of imperialism, but neither should we reject foods and arts outright on account of their cultural parentage. It's a tricky balance to be sure, but maybe it's at least worthy of a conversation.

Comment: The mid to late 1980's was the peak in the standard of living in Canada and much of the world. I made $11/hr and time and a half for a double shift in a factory job in 1984 while my university tuition was roughly $1000. It wasn't a bad life for the full-time factory workers..  My daughter's tuition is now over $13,000 in 2016/17. Student wages are not above $20/hr. The aluminum extrusion factory I worked in closed.  

The 1980's was a time of deficit financing as we still are in now. Governments started racking up debt in the 1980's to keep taxes low and provide services and government is now hitting its' limit. People started racking up debt when they found themselves unable to keep the expected standard of living. We have maxed out. Economic growth is slow and this is what we will face for the foreseeable future.

Comment: There is a huge flaw in the logic of buyers. One of timing. HC has a classic asset-liability mismatch in which the assets, GICs, etc. are leaving faster than the loan book can be scaled down.

Eventually, pools of loans will need to be sold to balance this mismatch.  It is unlikely the pools receive a par price for the following reason:
1. The pools are not uniform and well understood by the market
2. House price appreciation may make newer loans more vulnerable to losses.
3. The firm has had a problem  underwriting that will affect confidence in the data.
4. The seller is under distress and it is a large book
5. The buyer needs to be able to take over the servicing.

Leveraged firms often do not live long enough to realize the value in their assets. The equity is at the bottom of the stack. 

In my view the best case scenario is a sale of the business at a very small premium to the stock price by a firm that has the financing muscle to win the day.  Otherwise, it will be more losses.

Comment: The only really fair measure is per capita GHG emissions. In Alberta and SK, those stand at around 67 tonnes per person. In Ontario, around 14 tonnes, and in China around  7. (The US average is 19.9 tonnes per capita, a bit less than the Canadian average of 20.94.)  So, yes, if Canada is to have a credible voice in advocating for global reductions, it needs to do its fair share. (Even with our small population, we are in the list of the ten largest overall emitters.) That being said, a carbon tax might be a fairer and more transparent way of achieving cuts than a cap and trade system, particularly if the cost of carbon rises sufficiently to create a strong incentive to reduce emissions.

Comment: The PFD is not wealth distribution because it does not come from tax payers, which is why it boosts the economy. The money comes from the Alaska constitution granting the citizens of Alaska the mineral rights to state land. Back when oil was being pumped out like gang busters, someone had a brilliant idea of investing all the oil profit into the stock market as a huge principle, and then pay out the interest made from the principle to the Alaskan people, as opposed to simply cutting them a check for their share of the oil profit.
Long story short, the money IS ours, not the state's, because Alaskans (not Alaska) own the mineral rights that made the principle for the PFD. We are getting the interest from our share of the states minerals, that's all.

"Canadians, for instance, love to complain about banks and wireless providers but don’t exactly rush to embrace alternatives." That's typical of a lot of things besides banks and wireless providers.  Whining is cheap and easy.  Seeking alternatives and purchasing them may not be.  Unfair: Canadians haven't got a lock on cheap-and-easy decision-making. 

The United story is different from the Welles Fargo story in one way: it's a social media story. However, it's been over 25 years now since shaky amateur video of Rodney King turned the LAPD upside down; over 2 years since the big play phone videos gave the anti-Mubarak demonstrations in Egypt without the same effect.   

Ho-hum reaction will now set in.

Comment: Leave Obamacare alone to fail under its own deficiencies. Order companies who want  to participate in the market to follow a list of guidelines. These guidelines are:

9) Individuals who die with funds left in an HSA goes to their estate.

Comment: When I worked for the APP, the field crews were always out with a Bear Guard whether it was a 6 member team or 12 team party. Where were the personnel for this operation?  A bear guard could of be a very valuable resource whether at Pogo or Bird Ridge. We never had to put any down, but did see our fair share of bears & always scared them off before any harm to anyone.

At some point, any thoughtful male is going to ask himself "Really? What did I do and is any of this actually true?" Well, when I looked into it, I found out that not only was it not true but the opposite was actually the case.

I'm completely happy to accept equality of opportunity. I even believe it should be a foundation of our culture and society. What I can't abide is the idea that boys are simply defective girls. They're not. Boys and girls are different and always have been. It's not discriminatory to say that girls generally don't want to go into high-level physics. It's just the truth.

Comment: You're stats are probably correct, although my guess is that the proportion of Francophones who work in the federal public service in the Ottawa-Gatineau region is likely representative of the percentage of the Francophone population in a region that, after all, straddles the Ontario-Quebec border, which is understandably higher than is the case in the country as a whole. There's probably a similar tendency in Ontario's public service, where the proportion of immigrants and visible minorities, and particularly more recent hires, is likely more representative of the proportion of immigrants and visible minorities in the GTA, where Ontario's capital is located, than in the province as a whole. I'm not sure this is wholly problematic. Employers tend to select their employees from the workforce that's available to them.

Comment: Brett, this is not new.  In 2007 KHNL/KFVE, also owned by Raycom Media, also dropped regular sportscasts from newscasts.  Same reasons, same procedure.  We often led with sports, when a story rose to the level of appropriate importance.  We also were widely criticized internally and externally; though research showed over and over that sports fans had already received their news by the time the 5 p.m. or 6 p.m. news aired.  These days, with a digital device on every hip that continues to be the case.  When did Raycom acquire a station in Denver?  Last I knew the owners of Denver network affiliates were Tegna, Scripps, CBS, and FOX.  Dan Dennison, former news director, KHNL/K5 and KHON.
